summary.p: Halantas. A potential final M in l25 dattaM looks like a modern Bengali anusvāra (a small circle and a slanted stroke below it), while another in line 43 appears to be just a small circle, possibly with a slanted line above and to the right of it. Both of these may simply be large anusvāras with some superfluous strokes or damage. Final D in line 39 (if correctly read) is a da with a sinuous tail resembling a repha.

Other palaeographic observations. Anusvāra is above or, mostly when constrained by space, to the right of the character to which it belongs, but it may also be at median height to the right (l14, saṁghānvaye). Dependent au is clearly distinguished from o (e.g. l2 kauśikī), but o is also used in place of au (e.g. l6 potraḥ).

handDesc.handNote: This is the hand responsible for most of the document with large, slightly clumsily formed characters and slightly uneven lines.
The secondary hand, possibly of the same scribe in more haste, is responsible for the last three lines. Here, characters are much smaller and the ductus and line arrangement is more uneven.

app.note: It seems that the original ā of dhyā has been remodelled into nāṁ, so that the text now actually looks like °tanāṁ, but the corrector's intent is clear.
The characters yana are very narrow, and are probably a correction written over an original single character.
These characters are also quite narrow, especially yā. Some or all may be a correction over shorter original text.
I am less then certain of my emendation, but fairly sure that previous scholars were mistaken in believing these characters to be a chronogram. See the commentary.

The second ra may indeed be Ī (though not I) if the pair of dots on its two sides are not accidental. There is a similar dot only on the left-hand side of the first ra, so I prefer to believe that here too, the two dots are not part of the script. See line 37 for a definite Ī. The subscript component of the second conjunct with ś is wider and more squarish than that of the first, so I believe the first is v, while the second is c. Both of these assumptions may be wrong. R completely ignores the last character in the line. The body p and subscript y are definite, and the only plausible interpretation of the squiggle to the left of the y is a subscript l. I think the composer's intent was most probably something like pārameśvaraś ca pado ’nvayād ālabhyata, but due to the uncertainty of the reading and the corruptness of the language, this is only a tentative suggestion.

The first character looks like a figure 3 rotated 90 degrees counterclockwise, while I would expect initial I to be this shape with two dots below (compare line 36). It is patently not na; Ramesam may have intended ṇa for his reading, but that is also out of the question. The third character is unquestionably tya. The fourth is in my opinion ci, though R's vi cannot be excluded.

I cannot offer a confident and full reconstruction improvement. The reading is quite clear; the first character is definitely tha, not dha; the second is a little narrower than expected (correction over a narrower character?) but definitely pa. I do not know why R ignores the clear ṣṭya, or the clear double vowel marker on the top left and lower left of the following d. I believe that the composer's intent involved ādeśa-tuṣṭa-hr̥dayaiḥ (see line 10 for another superfluous subscript y). Perhaps dharmmādeśa- or dhavalādeśa- was meant. The former is more likely, since the latter makes less sense, and thapaladeśa is a fairly plausible scribal mistake for a hypothetical dharmma-Ādeśa.

The character sta looks as if the upper part was first engraved as g, then corrected to s, though this may just be a peculiarity of the scribe (compare si in line 20 below). There is no u attached to it.
The first part of the name may have been intended for kali, but the same form is used in line 23 too.
The first part of the name may have been intended for kali.
My emendation may be unwarranted, but I believe it is sound.
This stretch of text is blank in R's edition. It is not clear whether R did not bother to offer a reading, or if his manuscript was illegible and it was the typesetter who did not bother.
I conjecture that cintaka is a Sanskritisation and is used in the ablative here. The consonant read as d may instead be ḍ, in which case the text is perhaps to be segmented into cinta-kāḍṟāyirāvi-.

I do not understand how R arrived at his reading. The character with ll has a clear o of two strokes, one at top right and another at bottom left (just like mro in l28). I am not certain about the next character. Its body looks like ḻ to me, but may have been intended for ṟ with an omitted or indistinct cross-stroke. Its subscript part is probably ka, but may be ku.

R's edition is again blank for this word and the whole of line 33. The correct reading of ca may be ce, but the stroke that looks like a vowel marker is likely to be random damage, or perhaps a subsequent addition. The last character in line 32 may perhaps be mu or vū instead of vu.
In this string, ḍla may be dla, and I am uncertain about the character read as nū, which may be a misshapen ka or something else.
This may be non-standard (or plain bad) language for dikṣu Avadhi, understand diśi Avadhi. Compare line 36 below.
This chunk is again blank in R's edition.

Here, va (for vya) is added in the space between ya and di, at and below baseline and in small size. Interestingly, the right limb of ya is itself raised (branching out from the stem at median level), as if to create space for this va. There is, however, no sign that a limb at the regular baseline level was deleted, and elsewhere on the plates, ya is often similarly formed without any correction.
This may be non-standard (or plain bad) language for dikṣu Avadhi, understand diśi Avadhi. Compare line 33 above.
The first character may be di or ḍi. The last character in the line is an unambiguous initial I (compare line 13).
This may be non-standard (or plain bad) language for dikṣu Avadhi, understand diśi Avadhi. Compare line 33 above.

R's edition ignores the last two characters. This string is evidently a garbled version of asyopari na kenacid. I think o is in fact present on sy (with one stroke at the top of the tail of y, and another at the bottom left), though it is not quite clear and may be a subsequent addition. The last character is probably a final D, though by its shape it could also be rda.
The text expected here should be something along the lines of bādhā karttavyā yaḥ.
R's edition is blank here.
I emend tentatively. It is also possible that prayiti is a legitimate word in compound with the following sāda.
I assume that the word sāda appears twice here. In the first, da is narrower and more rounded than expected, while in the second, ā is attached to the right limb of the body rather than to the head.
These two characters are very narrow and are probably a correction written over a single original character.
My emendation is rather heavy-handed, but I am quite certain it is appropriate. R's reading is absurd.

div.p: Reported in 7A/1916-179 with discussion at 11421. Edited from estampages by Vepa Ramesam (C), with facsimiles, without translation. The present edition by Dániel Balogh is based on a collation of Ramesam's edition with his estampages. The published edition is replete with typographic errors and spelling inconsistencies, most of which are silently ignored here, and only significant differences from my reading are registered in the apparatus.
